title: Authorised Representative

	- definition:: A natural or legal person located or established in the Union who has received and accepted a written mandate from a provider of an AI system or a general-purpose AI model to, respectively, perform and carry out on its behalf the tasks and procedures established by this Regulation.




## Academic Context

- The concept of an "Authorised Representative" originates from regulatory frameworks designed to ensure accountability and compliance for AI systems, particularly within the European Union's AI Act.
  - It is grounded in legal theory concerning delegated authority and liability, where a natural or legal person acts on behalf of another entity to fulfil regulatory obligations.
  - The academic foundation draws on principles of administrative law and compliance management, emphasising clear mandates and responsibilities to manage risks associated with AI deployment.

## Current Landscape (2025)

- The EU AI Act, effective from August 2025, mandates that providers of AI systems or general-purpose AI models appoint an Authorised Representative located within the Union if they are established outside it.
  - This representative must have a written mandate to perform regulatory tasks on behalf of the provider, ensuring compliance with the AI Act’s requirements.
  - The role includes liaising with authorities, maintaining technical documentation, and facilitating market surveillance.
- In the UK, no equivalent statutory role exists due to the absence of a dedicated AI Act; instead, the UK maintains a principles-based, sector-specific regulatory approach without prescriptive mandates for Authorised Representatives.
  - UK firms engaging with the EU market must comply with the EU’s Authorised Representative requirements, often appointing representatives in EU jurisdictions.
- Notable organisations in North England (Manchester, Leeds, Newcastle, Sheffield) involved in AI innovation increasingly engage with these regulatory frameworks, often appointing Authorised Representatives to access EU markets.
- Technical capabilities of Authorised Representatives include regulatory expertise, legal compliance management, and often multilingual communication skills to bridge providers and EU authorities.
- Standards and frameworks continue to evolve, with the EU AI Act setting a precedent; the UK’s regulatory bodies (e.g., ICO, FCA) provide guidance but no direct equivalent role.

## Research & Literature

- Key academic sources include:
  - Veale, M., & Borgesius, F. Z. (2021). *Demystifying the Draft EU Artificial Intelligence Act*. Computer Law & Security Review, 41, 105567. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.clsr.2021.105567
  - Wachter, S., Mittelstadt, B., & Floridi, L. (2017). *Why a Right to Explanation of Automated Decision-Making Does Not Exist in the General Data Protection Regulation*. International Data Privacy Law, 7(2), 76–99. https://doi.org/10.1093/idpl/ipx005
- Ongoing research focuses on the practical implementation of Authorised Representatives, their liability exposure, and cross-jurisdictional challenges in AI governance.

## UK Context

- The UK government has delayed introducing a dedicated AI regulatory framework, opting instead for a flexible, principles-based approach emphasising innovation and sectoral oversight.
  - The Digital Regulation Cooperation Forum (DRCF) coordinates regulatory efforts across UK bodies, but no statutory Authorised Representative role exists domestically.
- North England’s AI hubs, notably in Manchester and Leeds, actively develop AI technologies and often engage with EU regulations by appointing Authorised Representatives to comply with the EU AI Act.
- Regional case studies reveal that UK-based AI providers targeting EU markets typically contract legal and compliance firms in the EU to act as Authorised Representatives, ensuring smooth market access.
- The UK’s Data Use and AI Bill (expected post-2026) may influence future roles but currently does not mandate Authorised Representatives.

## Future Directions

- Emerging trends suggest increased formalisation of the Authorised Representative role within the EU, potentially expanding responsibilities as AI systems grow more complex.
- Anticipated challenges include managing cross-border liability, ensuring transparency, and harmonising UK-EU regulatory approaches to avoid fragmentation.
- Research priorities involve developing best practices for mandates, clarifying liability frameworks, and exploring technological tools to support Authorised Representatives in compliance monitoring.

2. Wachter, S., Mittelstadt, B., & Floridi, L. (2017). Why a Right to Explanation of Automated Decision-Making Does Not Exist in the General Data Protection Regulation. *International Data Privacy Law*, 7(2), 76–99. https://doi.org/10.1093/idpl/ipx005  
3. King & Spalding. (2025). EU & UK AI Round-up – July 2025.  
4. GDPR Local. (2025). UK AI Regulation: Current Status and Outlook.  
5. Osborne Clarke. (2025). Artificial Intelligence | UK Regulatory Outlook October 2025.  
6. UK Government. (2025). Artificial Intelligence Playbook for the UK Government.
